conclusion: To determine the maximum distance the piston can reach from the bottom of the cylinder when the elevator moves vertically, we need to analyze the forces acting on the piston in both stationary and accelerated states.
In the stationary state, the net force acting on the piston must be zero.
The upward force exerted by the gas on the piston (P_0S) must balance the downward forces due to the weight of the piston and the cylinder minus the tension in the rope.
The force exerted by the gas on the piston is P_0S = 300 N.
The total downward force on the piston includes the weights of the piston and the cylinder: Mg + mg = 75 N.
The rope tension is F = 120 N.
Since the net force is zero: P_0S - (Mg + mg) - F = 0, which confirms our setup.
When the elevator accelerates upwards with acceleration a, the forces acting on the piston change according to the applied acceleration.
The new force exerted by the gas on the piston will be different because the gas also accelerates with the piston.
Using Newton's second law for the piston: F_net = ma_piston.
The new force exerted by the gas on the piston is now P_1S = P_0S + ma.
The upward force exerted by the gas on the piston must balance the downward forces due to the weight of the piston and the cylinder plus the tension in the rope.
